title: Want to → Wanna
description: In casual speech, 'want to' is almost always pronounced as 'wanna'. This is one of the most common reductions in English and happens automatically for native speakers.
tips: Listen for the 't' sound disappearing completely
The 'to' becomes a quick 'uh' sound (schwa)
This reduction happens in questions too: 'Do you wanna...?'

title: Going to → Gonna
description: When expressing future intent, 'going to' reduces to 'gonna'. This is standard in spoken English and used by all native speakers in casual conversation.
exampleSentence: I'm going to call you later.
tips: The 'going' loses its '-ing' ending entirely
'Gonna' is never written formally but always spoken
Listen for it in phrases like 'gonna be', 'gonna do', 'gonna have'

title: Have to → Hafta
description: The phrase 'have to' expressing obligation becomes 'hafta' in natural speech. The 'v' sound changes to 'f' and the 'to' reduces to a schwa.
tips: Notice how 'v' becomes 'f' - this is called devoicing
The stress stays on 'haf', not on 'ta'
'Has to' becomes 'hasta' with the same pattern

title: Got to → Gotta
description: Another way to express obligation, 'got to' becomes 'gotta'. The 't' in 'got' often becomes a flap sound, and 'to' reduces completely.
tips: Often used interchangeably with 'hafta'
The 't' may sound like a quick 'd' (flapping)
Very common in informal speech: 'You gotta try this!'

title: Kind of → Kinda
description: The phrase 'kind of' meaning 'somewhat' or 'sort of' reduces to 'kinda'. The 'd' and 'of' merge together into a simple schwa ending.
tips: Used as a softener: 'I kinda like it' sounds less direct
The 'of' completely disappears into a schwa
Very common in American English casual speech

title: Lot of → Lotta
description: When saying 'a lot of', the phrase reduces to 'a lotta'. The 'f' in 'of' disappears and the 'o' becomes a schwa.
exampleSentence: There are a lot of people here.
exampleTranscription: There are a lotta people here.
tips: The 't' often becomes a flap (sounds like a quick 'd')
Listen for this in 'lotta time', 'lotta money', 'lotta work'
The word 'a' before 'lotta' may also reduce to just a schwa

title: Out of → Outta
description: The phrase 'out of' reduces to 'outta'. The 't' at the end of 'out' connects with the following vowel, and 'of' becomes a schwa.
tips: Very common in phrases like 'outta time', 'outta luck', 'outta control'
The 't' becomes a flap between the vowels
Often heard as a complete phrase: 'Get outta here!' (expression of disbelief)

title: Sort of → Sorta
description: Similar to 'kinda', 'sort of' reduces to 'sorta'. It means 'somewhat' or 'in a way' and is very common in casual speech.
tips: Used interchangeably with 'kinda'
The 't' becomes a flap sound
Often used to hedge or soften statements

title: Let me → Lemme
description: The phrase 'let me' becomes 'lemme' in fast speech. The 't' disappears and the two words merge into one.
tips: The 't' completely disappears
Common in requests: 'Lemme see', 'Lemme know', 'Lemme try'
The stress is on the first syllable: LEM-me

title: Give me → Gimme
description: In casual speech, 'give me' becomes 'gimme'. The 'v' sound changes and the two words merge completely.
tips: The 'v' changes to 'm' through assimilation
Very common in informal requests: 'Gimme a second'
Often heard in the phrase 'Gimme a break!' (expressing frustration)
